results.headline: Adventures of a Former Actor
results.summary_short: “Looking for Palladin” is a semicoherent, overacted mélange of travelogue, farce and suds.

results.headline: The Union at the Polls
results.summary_short: More than anything else, “Labor Day” is a slickly produced 76-minute commercial for the Service Employees International Union.

results.headline: Baby Sitter, Beware: That Top Step Is a Lulu

results.headline: A Writer, a Snake and Bodily Waste
results.summary_short: Timing, good jokes and characters you can laugh with and at are mostly missing from “Gentlemen Broncos.”

results.summary_short: The latest installment of the movie franchise is as customer-service-oriented as ever.

results.headline: Bodies in Motion
results.summary_short: This seductively fluid and tactile drama explores love and identity through the prism of the female body and the rights of its owner.

results.summary_short: Jonathan Parker’s acutely witty art-world satire carries off a tricky balancing act.

results.summary_short: The South Korean director Hong Sang-soo unleashes yet another emotionally stunted antihero in “Night and Day.”

results.headline: Manhattan Mom, Burning Home Fires at Both Ends
results.summary_short: You’ll need something to occupy your thoughts while watching this film, which seems to suffer from its heroine’s tendency toward distraction.

results.headline: Examining a Man Who Was (or Wasn’t?) a Holocaust Hero
results.summary_short: Gaylen Ross’s methodical but overlong documentary pores over the life of Rudolf Kasztner, a leader of a Hungarian Jewish aid and rescue committee in World War II.

results.headline: In Satan’s Church, an Eden Besieged
results.summary_short: Women: intrinsically evil or tragically misunderstood? If this strikes you as a fruitful topic of discussion, then you may wish to see — or perhaps I should say endure — Lars von Trier’s new film.
